### Summary Description of the Timor-Leste ICS Project

#### 1. Technologies/Measures to be Implemented
The Timor-Leste Improved Cookstove (ICS) Project is designed to enhance energy efficiency and reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by distributing and implementing energy-efficient cookstoves across all districts of Timor-Leste. The project will replace traditional three-stone stoves with jumbo stove-type ICS, which boast a thermal efficiency of 38%. These improved cookstoves significantly reduce firewood consumption and harmful emissions. The initiative also includes community training on stove maintenance and proper usage, continuous monitoring through surveys, and the potential future introduction of advanced technologies.

#### 2. Location of the Project
This project spans the entire nation of Timor-Leste, encompassing all its districts. Key municipalities involved in the project include Dili, Manatuto, Aileu, Ermera, Likisa, Ainaro, Lautém, Viqueque, Baucau, Ambeno, Atauro, Manufahi, Bobonaro, and Covalima.

#### 3. Generation of GHG Emission Reductions or Carbon Dioxide Removals
The project aims to generate significant GHG emission reductions by replacing 200,000 traditional three-stone cookstoves with improved cookstoves (ICS). These ICS units require less firewood, thereby decreasing the consumption of non-renewable woody biomass and reducing CO2 emissions. Additionally, the project will help curb deforestation and enhance local ecosystems. Emission reductions will be calculated using the VMR0006 methodology, focusing on the mass of non-renewable woody biomass saved. The project is projected to reduce approximately 507,463 tonnes of CO2 equivalent (tCO2e) annually, totaling about 5,074,630 tCO2e over a ten-year crediting period.

#### 4. Scenario Existing Prior to the Implementation of the Project
Prior to the implementation of this project, the majority of households in Timor-Leste, particularly in rural areas, relied on traditional three-stone stoves for cooking. These stoves were highly inefficient, consuming large amounts of firewood (approximately 3.45 tonnes per stove per year) and causing chronic health issues due to smoke inhalation. Previous pilot programs aimed at introducing improved cookstoves were unsuccessful in scaling up due to high upfront costs, lack of resources, poor technology selection, and insufficient community involvement.

#### 5. Estimate of Annual Average and Total Reductions and Removals
The project is estimated to achieve an annual average reduction and removal of 507,463 tCO2e. Over a ten-year period, the total reduction and removal is projected to be 5,074,630 tCO2e.

This comprehensive approach to implementing energy-efficient cookstoves in Timor-Leste not only addresses environmental concerns but also promotes health benefits and sustainable development within the community.
